related.description: American students are bored by math, science and engineering. They buy smartphones and tablets by the millions but don't pursue the skills necessary to build them. Engineers and physicists are often portrayed as clueless geeks on television, and despite the high pay and the importance of such jobs to the country's future, the vast majority of high school graduates don't want to go after them.

title: Cooper Union Ends Free Tuition
content:
UPDATED | Cooper Union said Tuesday it will charge tuition to incoming freshmen starting in fall 2014, breaking with a century-old tradition of free education at the prestigious college in Manhattan's East Village.

The art, architecture and engineering school plans to charge students half of what it considers full tuition and subsidize the rest, said Mark Epstein, chairman of the board of trustees. Full tuition for the 2012-13 school year was $38,550.

The trustees voted last week to charge students after deliberating over 18 months to figure out how to close a mounting budget gap. School officials last year moved to charge students in an expanded graduate program and add other revenue-producing courses.

The board decision Tuesday wasn't unanimous, but Mr. Epstein wouldn't disclose the vote tally.

"Tuition being charged is not gravy," he said to students and faculty members gathered at the school's Great Hall. "This is money that is necessary to keep us going."

The decision bucks the school's unofficial motto of "free as air and water," which many, including the school, often attribute to founder Peter Cooper.

"The free [as] air and water turned out to be a myth," Mr. Epstein said.

A November 2011 story in the Journal looked at Cooper Union's initial debate over charging its students - a proposal that prompted reluctance from students and school officials, who saw the tuition-free tradition as a vital tradition: "It's the essence of who we are," said trustee Don Blauweiss in an interview at the time. "Therefore it means a great deal."

Consultants told the college about 25% of students would likely still receive full tuition, Mr. Epstein said. When running the numbers, he said the school found an unusual problem: It couldn't analyze what percentage of current students would need financial aid because it usually didn't bother asking students about their family's financial situation.

The school has a projected $12 million annual deficit and is facing rising expenses, such as health-care costs that are increasing 7.5% annually, Mr. Epstein said. Some assets, such as the Chrysler Building, have helped sustain the university to some extent. But Mr. Epstein said even with rent increases after 2019, the rate of growth wouldn't keep up with inflation.

The school has drawn from investments and fundraising to provide tuition-free education for about 1,000 students. For years, trustees said, the school hired presidents for their academic credentials, not their fund-raising prowess.

In a tense and at times hostile meeting with students and faculty members, Mr. Epstein took written questions about the decision.

"This format of asking questions is insulting," complained one person in the audience. Mr. Epstein responded: "Maybe so. Being yelled at, like the last meeting, was offensive."

Students and faculty members at the meeting Tuesday worried that some high-quality students would choose other schools if Cooper Union began charging tuition. "If people are coming here merely because we're free," Mr. Epstein replied, "we're doing something wrong."
